page.title: 01 Chaucer's England.
page.content: The ancient Pilgrims Way track meanders through Chartham Hatch towards Canterbury.If Chaucer were to retrace his journey today,much would have changed,but he would still recognise something of its essential spirit.Strange would be the cars,the televisions,telephones and suchlike,but the woodcutters cutting the coppice nearby,and the farm workers,the hearts of these folk would be the same as the hearts of Chaucer's characters.Men and women whose lives are merged with the nature and the place of their work.Today,farming and carefully managed woodland dominate the area.Orchards abound.A major road,the new A2,scars the countryside along the route of the old Roman Road to London,but the rest of the few roads are narrow country roads.It is ideal countryside for the rambler.
